intro: Fimbristylis brevicollis, commonly known as the short-necked sedge, is a flowering plant native to tropical and subtropical regions of Australia. It is a member of the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges, and is characterized by its grass-like appearance with triangular stems. The plant typically grows in wetland environments, such as swampy areas and seasonally flooded soils. It produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in spikelets, which are clustered along the upper part of the stem. Fimbristylis brevicollis plays an important ecological role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various aquatic and terrestrial organisms.
